1) let’s count our new orbit
Our circular speed is about 30 km per second VGM/a and our velocity will be directed perpendicular to the radius. That means that we would fly about 77 million kilometers. So our distance to the Sun will be V0,5^2au+1au=1,25au.
2) let’s count Earth equilibrium temperature
T=T*(1-A)^(1/4)*V(R/2D)=175K=-97,6C
We call habitable planets those on which liquid water can exist in theory. Here it’s not able. in addition, it will be incredibly difficult to survive in such conditions

First off, cool episode. Second off, not how orbital mechanics works.

When discussing the new orbit of earth, you forgot to consider that earth still retains the same momentum that it had prior to moving away from the location the sun was previously at. Which means the new orbit, which starts much higher than before, would also travel much closer to the sun at its lowest point in the orbit. So you would have a freezing cold season, and a freakin hot season.

Also:

Since your change isn't just an altitude change and your initial vector changes before the sun returns, earth would still not be at it's highest point for at least 4 months. Which makes the math even more fun. Upon request I will present math for this, as opposed to my 4 month estimate.

If the sun reappeared after 1 month Earth's orbit would become highly elliptical.  It would retain the exact velocity it had at 1AU which when translated to 170 million miles out would make the Earth aphelion closer to current Jupiter.  We might get away with this as all the other planets would go into highly elliptical orbits.  Most importantly the Earth's year would suddenly extend to around 5 of our current years and a big portion of the year is going to get mighty cold as the sun's intensity further out could be as low as 4% the current intensity.  You'll need winter wear even in the tropics.
